name: places/ChIJgzkJ5zr2wokR13Dtl9reHZc
formattedAddress: 362 Riverside Dr, New York, NY 10025, USA
adrFormatAddress: 362 Riverside Dr, New York, NY 10025-2755, USA

originalText.text:
The room is okay and the kitchen is pretty well-equipped. But the dormitory doesn't provide pillow or blanket despite charging 1316 USD per month. It is a little bit far from Columbia University by walking, but this place is near to subway station. So, if you commute through Subway, it is only one station away, and thus, took only 5 minutes to reach Earl gate. Anyway, the security is good because there is always a guard at the door (24 hours). There are not many facilities here (no gym!) But at least people are generally nice here and there are washing machines and dyers in the basement.
Ps. If you come in early June, you may feel hot because there is no air-conditioner. But the air-conditioner will be installed by the end of June.

originalText.text:
Pros: if there is any maintenance issue, email the superintendent DIRECTLY, and it would be fixed promptly. The apartments are thoroughly cleaned once a week. If you don't have to expect a gust overnight, this is the best place for you. Kitchen is a nice bonding place with roommates.

Cons: staffs can be found rude and ill-mannered. There is a lady at the mailroom whom I never found positive and friendly. The superintendent himself can be over edge time to time. I had to YELL back in retaliation a few times, just do that if you don't want to yield your dignity.

During my stay, there was an RA (residential advisor) who lacked basic behavioral skill. My friends tried complaining against her to the University Housing Assistance (UHA) office multiple times, but they seemed to allow her insolence to continue turning deaf heir to the concerns. I hope the scenario will change sometimes in future.

If you expect overnight guests, the building seems to view this a big burden and may try to NOT issue you a guest pass.

Lastly, there wasn't any stairs to the basement but elevator where there are bike room and laundry room. If you have to do laundry once a week, you should be good. However, if you ride a bike, keep in mind the waiting time in front of the elevator! Stubbornly, the superintendent aims to exercise no bike storage rule on the sidewalk, which should belong to the city.

originalText.text:
terrible upkeep.  This place is partially (if not fully) funded/supported by Columbia University.  It has a pretty impressive security desk... but keep visitor logs available for EVERYONE to see just sitting out..... sooo... if I wanted to see what person so-and-so brought to their room, or needed a copy of their signature then it is right there for me.

Enough about the security, it has a good id badging system for the guard to know who's in the building at all times.  But they need to revisit how they manage visitor logs.

The building is in a perpetual state of disrepair.  It has 10 floors, a staircase, a working elevator and an out of service elevator.  The elevator is slow and half thd lights do not work.  I felt as if in a 3rd world country, not a 1500 a month room.  Yes, room.  The rooms for students are tiny, do not have basic air conditioning (but were a steady 90℉ in late spring), thank goodness we we're not needing to continue our curriculum into late summer.  This place is so hot that both security doors in the lobby are wide open to cool down the building, and fill it with pests at the same time.  Great way to treat your ivy league students Columbia!  I wouldn't be so critical of the UNIVERSITY's role in this if they didn't put signs up everywhere in the building about how the students need to keep their spaces immaculate, need to have daily and weekly communal cleaning schedules, and were supposed to send people to  verify this was done.  Yet never happened during the two months my family member was there.  There is a communal kitchen and living room with both seperate men and women rsstrooms in each quad.  The men freely just go inside the women's restroom (regardless of the woman is taking a shower, using the toilet, or dressing)... and the women are responsible for cleaning the womens restroom.  Unsat.

The kitchen I noted above was disgusting.  Half sink full of pans, half full of food.  Refrigerator full of mold, and filth, and old food.

Bottom line: parents do not spend your good earned money on this school supported slum.  Ensure your child is safe while at that school.  Whether an airborne pathogen sickens them from the filth of this place, or the disrepair of the building itself..... save your money and look for better places.  Columbia needs to seriously inspect this property and take it from their authorized list of outside dorms.

originalText.text: The worst dorm I have ever lived. The facility people were so rude and unkind.

text.text: The worst dorm I have ever lived. The facility people were so rude and unkind.

originalText.text: Public safety and staff are the worst people. Rude, incompetent, brainless, arrogant.

text.text: Public safety and staff are the worst people. Rude, incompetent, brainless, arrogant.
